questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the procedure shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primigravida

 

The procedure shown is an External Cephalic Version (ECV), a technique used to turn a breech fetus to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor to facilitate a vaginal delivery. While it is generally more challenging to perform ECV in primigravida (first-time pregnant women) due to a tenser abdominal wall, it is not a contraindication. The procedure can still be performed in primigravida with caution and proper monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: This is a definite contraindication to ECV because the placenta covers the cervix, preventing safe vaginal delivery. Attempting ECV in such cases could cause placental abruption or severe bleeding, necessitating a cesarean section regardless.

 

Option C. Multiple pregnancy: ECV is contraindicated in multiple pregnancies (twins or more) because manipulating one fetus could adversely affect the position of the other, making the procedure unsafe.

 

Option D. Ruptured membranes: When membranes are ruptured, there is a loss of amniotic fluid (liquor), which is necessary for the maneuverability of the fetus during ECV. Without sufficient amniotic fluid, the procedure is difficult, risky, and not feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primigravida is not a contraindication for ECV, though it may be technically more challenging compared to multiparous women. Key contraindications to ECV include placenta previa, multiple pregnancy, and ruptured membranes.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

 

The symptoms described in this case—fever, rash, sore throat, and body aches—following a thorn prick injury suggest the possibility of scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). Scarlet fever typically presents with a diffuse erythematous rash, which may be papular, along with other symptoms such as a sore throat, body aches, and the characteristic "strawberry tongue."

 

Key Points:

 

  • Scarlet Fever and GAS: Scarlet fever is most commonly caused by GAS and is characterized by the production of pyrogenic (erythrogenic) exotoxin, leading to the rash and other systemic symptoms.
  • Empirical Antibiotic Treatment:
    • Amoxicillin + Clavulanate: This combination is a first-line treatment for infections caused by GAS, particularly when there is a concern for beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes, allowing amoxicillin to remain effective against the bacteria.
    • Penicillin or Amoxicillin alone is generally the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, but adding clavulanate broadens the spectrum to cover potential mixed infections.
  • Diagnostic Confirmation: While empirical treatment is initiated, a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture for Streptococcus should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GAS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is typically reserved for more severe infections requiring hospitalization. It is not the first choice for uncomplicated scarlet fever.

 

Option C. Vancomycin. and Option D. Meropenem: These are higher-tier antibiotics reserved for severe or resistant infections, often guided by culture and sensitivity results. They are not typically used as first-line treatment in cases of suspected scarlet fever or mild GAS infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Togavirus

 

Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

 

Rubella (German measles)

 

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

 

Congenital rubella syndrome:

 

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term "blueberry muffin syndrome."

 

Expanded rubella syndrome:

 

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome.
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flavivirus: This group includes viruses like the West Nile virus and Dengue virus, not Rubella.

 

Option C. Paramyxovirus: Includes viruses like measles and mumps, which are clinically distinct from rubella.

 

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: This is the family of viruses that includes the influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text:
What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Pulmonary
  2. Aortic
  3. Mitral
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3
 

The sequence of cardiac sounds as they're perceived on the left side of the chest, from top to bottom, is outlined below:

 

  1. Pulmonary - detected in the second intercostal space.
  2. Aortic - can be heard at the neoaortic region or Erb's point, situated in the second intercostal space.
  3. Mitral - observed at the fifth intercostal space.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4-8%

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is higher than in non-consanguineous marriages. The risk depends on several factors, such as the prevalence of genetic diseases in the population, the degree of consanguinity, and the genetic makeup of the couple.

 

The estimated risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population's risk of around 2-4%. However, the risk can vary widely depending on the specific genetic diseases and the population's prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is estimated to be around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population risk of approximately 2-4%.

choices.text: Interstitial cystitis
Polypoid cystitis

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.

 

  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder. It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages. It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pain and frequent, urgent urination. It does not present with yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis presents with polypoid or papillary projections in the bladder, often due to chronic irritation, such as long-term catheter use. It does not show the specific histopathological features of malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder characterized by symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency of urination. The cystoscopy findings would typically show an inflamed, red mucosa, not yellow-white plaques.

 

Educational objective:

 

Malakoplakia is characterized by multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone, as seen on cystoscopy, and histopathological findings of foamy macrophages with PAS-positive cytoplasm and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. This condition is associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis, commonly affecting immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: If percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. what is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22%

 

Explanation:

 

  • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%.
  • Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds.
    Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, thymine (T) always pairs with adenine (A), forming a complementary base pair. Similarly, cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). The base pairing in DNA is always complementary, and the total percentage of purines (adenine + guanine) equals the total percentage of pyrimidines (thymine + cytosine).

choices.text: Amniotic fluid volume
Daily fetal movement count

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of biophysical profile? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:

 

Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not a component of the BPP. DFMC, often assessed using Cardiff’s count of 10, is a separate method for monitoring fetal movements.

 

  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
    3. Fetal movements
    4. Fetal tone
    5. Fetal breathing movements
  • A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention.
  • Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid volume: Amniotic fluid volume is a component of the BPP and helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

 

Option B. Fetal tone: Fetal tone is another component of the BPP, assessing the baby's muscle tone.

 

Option D. Non-stress test: Non-stress test (NST) is part of the BPP and evaluates the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: NST, AFV, fetal movements, fetal tone, and fetal breathing movements. Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not part of the BPP.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 122

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with sudden severe headache. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage)

 

The CT scan shows hyperdensity (bright white areas) within the CSF cisterns, indicating the presence of blood. This presentation is typical of a Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH), which is often caused by a ruptured aneurysm, particularly in the circle of Willis, as confirmed by the accompanying CT angiography. The sudden severe headache experienced by the patient, often described as a "thunderclap headache," is characteristic of SAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SDH (Subdural Hemorrhage): SDH typically appears as a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid membrane. It is not confined to the CSF cisterns and does not present with the sudden onset severe headache seen in SAH.

 

Option C. EDH (Epidural Hemorrhage): EDH is characterized by a biconvex, lens-shaped appearance on imaging. It is usually associated with trauma and does not involve the subarachnoid space or present with CSF cistern hyperdensity.

 

Option D. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, often due to trauma or surgical procedures. It shows air density areas on imaging, which appear black, unlike the hyperdense (white) blood seen in SAH. The classic sign associated with pneumocephalus is the Mount Fuji sign, which is not seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAH presents with sudden, severe headache and is identified on CT by hyperdensity in the CSF cisterns. The most common cause is aneurysmal rupture, best evaluated using CT angiography.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal capsule

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure situated between the thalamus and the lentiform nucleus. It contains important pathways that carry motor and sensory information to and from the cerebral cortex. In the provided image, the marked structure lies outside the thalamus and appears as a bundle of white matter, which is characteristic of the internal capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: The thalamus is located medial to the internal capsule and is not the structure marked in the image. The thalamus serves as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex.

 

Option B. Lentiform nucleus: The lentiform nucleus, which includes the putamen and globus pallidus, is situated lateral to the internal capsule. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Option C. Caudate: The caudate nucleus is located superior to the thalamus and medial to the internal capsule. It is also not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule is a key white matter structure that lies between the thalamus and the lentiform nucleus, transmitting important motor and sensory pathways to the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100hz tuning fork)?(INICET 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency - 1/contraction period

 

Where the contraction period is the time taken from the end of latent period (Beginning of the upstroke) to maximum force of contraction(maximum height of upstroke i.e beginning of the downstroke).

 

In the given diagram, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means, the tracer (Waves shown below the main graph) recorded 100 waves per second, below the twitch graph.

 

Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.

 

The formula used to calculate the tetanizing frequency is:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / contraction period

 

Substituting the values obtained:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / 0.05 sec = 20/sec

 

Therefore, the tetanizing frequency of the muscle is 20 per second.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum tetanizing frequency of a muscle is determined by the reciprocal of the contraction period.

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.text: Key feature of depression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low mood

 

The most important feature of depression is low mood, also known as sadness of mood.

 

Depression is primarily a mood disorder, and while other symptoms such as sleep disturbances, guilt feelings, negative thoughts, suicidal ideations, anhedonia (loss of interest in pleasurable activities), and loss of appetite may be present, the key defining characteristic remains the persistent low mood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal ideations are incorrect as they are not the key feature of depression. While suicidal thoughts may occur in severe cases of depression, they are not the primary defining symptom of the disorder.


Option C. Loss of interest in pleasurable activity, or anhedonia, is incorrect as it is not the most important feature of depression. Although anhedonia is a common symptom in depression, it is not the key defining characteristic of the disorder.

 

Option D. Loss of Appetite is incorrect as it is not the key feature of depression. Changes in appetite, including loss of appetite, can occur in depression but do not represent the core symptom of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low mood, or sadness of mood, is the key defining feature of depression, as depression is primarily a mood disorder.

choices.text: Clean cut incised wound

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he was attacked by his lover’s husband with an axe. On examination, crushing of the hair bull was seen. Identify the type of wound? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lacerated wound  

 

  • The type of wound in which the crushing of the hair bulb is seen is a lacerated wound.
  • Laceration- A laceration is a wound that is produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged
  • It is produced by blunt weapons or heavy relatively sharp-edged weapons such as axe.
  • In scalp lacerations hair bulbs, nerves, and vessels, are irregularly torn and crushed

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Clean cut incised wound: Typically has clean, sharp edges caused by sharp instruments like knives or razors.
  • Option C. Chop wound: While an axe can cause a chop wound, the presence of crushed hair bulbs suggests more of a laceration pattern.
  • Option D. Avulsion injury: Involves the skin and underlying tissues being forcibly detached from the body.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.
  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.
  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.
  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact
  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text: Calculate Maternal Mortality Ratio in a population of 2 lacs, with 4000 live births, Death were 4 by PPH, 2 deaths by electrocution, 2 deaths by sepsis, 2 deaths by abortion, 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, and 5 still births. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 250 per 1 lac

 

Explanation:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

 

Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days of delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.

 

In the given scenario, the maternal deaths are:

 

  • 4 deaths by postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
  • 2 deaths by sepsis
  • 2 deaths by abortion
  • 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy

 

These deaths should be included in the calculation as they are related to maternity or its complications.

 

The deaths due to electrocution and stillbirths are not included in the calculation of MMR.

 

Therefore, the total number of maternal deaths is 10 (4 + 2 + 2 + 2).

 

The number of live births is given as 4,000.

 

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) × 100,000

 

= (10 / 4,000) × 100,000

 

= 250 per 1,00,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths (deaths related to maternity or its complications) by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 400 mEq

 

Explanation:

 

The sodium deficit can be calculated using the formula:

 

Sodium Deficit=Total Body Water×(Desired Sodium−Actual Sodium)

 

For females, the Total Body Water (TBW) is 50% of body weight

 

TBW=0.5×Body Weight

 

Here, the body weight is 40 kg:

 

TBW=0.5×40 kg=20 LTBW=0.5×40 kg=20 L

 

The desired sodium concentration is 140 mEq/L and the actual sodium concentration is 120

 

mEq/L:

 

Sodium Deficit=20 L×(140 mEq/L−120 mEq/L) =400 mEq

 

Therefore, the sodium deficit is 400 mEq.

 

Educational Objectives

 

The sodium deficit for a female weighing 40 kg with a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L, aiming for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L, is 400 mEq.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on this image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

The image shows a chest X-ray with dextrocardia, a condition where the heart is positioned on the right side of the chest. This is a key feature of situs inversus, which is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome.

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by a triad of clinical features: recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. The presence of situs inversus, as indicated by dextrocardia on the X-ray, is a distinguishing feature that confirms the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, characterized by thick, sticky mucus that can clog the airways and lead to infections. It does not typically present with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Young syndrome also involves recurrent sinusitis and bronchiectasis, similar to Kartagener syndrome. However, it is distinguished by infertility due to azoospermia rather than situs inversus. The absence of dextrocardia or situs inversus on imaging excludes Young syndrome as the correct answer.

 

Option D. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal inflammation leading to crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal block, and enlarged nasal cavities. It does not involve bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, or situs inversus, making it unrelated to the features seen in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Kartagener syndrome is identified by the presence of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (including dextrocardia), which is clearly visible in the chest X-ray provided.

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

 

Following a renal biopsy, it is crucial to monitor the patient for potential complications, including bleeding and hematoma formation.

 

2. Observation post-biopsy: Patients should be observed for 24 hours following a renal biopsy to monitor for complications such as bleeding or infection.

 

3. Dark red clots in urine: Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy can indicate a hematoma. This is a potential complication that needs to be monitored.

 

4. Abdominal fat pad biopsy: Patients with systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo an abdominal fat pad biopsy as an alternative to a renal biopsy. This method can help diagnose systemic amyloidosis with less risk compared to a renal biopsy.

 

Other Option:

 

1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: This statement is incorrect. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can indeed be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy. The biopsy helps in identifying the characteristic histological changes associated with FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniere’s disease

 

Given the patient's symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, along with the audiogram showing a sensorineural hearing loss pattern with a dip at low to mid frequencies, the most likely diagnosis is Option B, Meniere’s disease.

 

Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The audiogram typically shows a sensorineural hearing loss that predominantly affects the low to mid frequencies, which is consistent with the audiogram provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo): Is a disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include vertigo that is usually triggered by changes in the position of the head. It doesn't typically cause hearing loss, which we can see in the audiogram.

 

Option C. Vestibular neuronitis: Is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo and imbalance, but it does not usually affect hearing, so the audiogram would not show the hearing loss pattern we see here.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Is a middle ear disease that usually presents with conductive hearing loss, particularly in younger adults, and it does not cause vertigo or tinnitus as primary symptoms. The audiogram for otosclerosis would show an air-bone gap, which is not present in the audiogram provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and an audiogram showing low to mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss is Meniere’s disease.

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in which type of dementia? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dementia with lewy body

 

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification where the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by a similar-looking stranger.

 

While Capgras syndrome is usually seen in Schizophrenia, it can also occur in patients with dementia. Among the various types of dementia, Capgras syndrome is most commonly associated with Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), followed by Alzheimer's disease. In a patient with Capgras syndrome and dementia, the patient may believe that their spouse or a family member has been replaced by an identical impostor, leading to conflicts and distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease is the second most common type of dementia associated with Capgras syndrome, after dementia with Lewy bodies.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia is not typically associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Option D. Frontotemporal dementia is not commonly associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capgras syndrome, a delusion of misidentification where a patient believes a familiar person has been replaced by an identical impostor, is most commonly seen in dementia with Lewy bodies, followed by Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer is bitten by a scorpion. Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prazosin

 

Antidote for scorpion venom: Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom.

 

Effects of scorpion venom: hemolytic and neurotoxic

 

Symptoms of scorpion venom

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: A cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat anticholinergic toxicity. It is not effective against scorpion venom.

 

Option B. Norepinephrine: A vasopressor used to treat severe hypotension. It is not suitable as an antidote for scorpion venom, which can cause hypertension and other systemic effects.

 

Option D. Atropine: An anticholinergic drug used to treat bradycardia and certain types of poisonings. It is not effective against scorpion venom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom by counteracting the severe cardiovascular and systemic effects induced by the venom.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

 

Aspartate and glutamate are both acidic amino acids that contain a carboxylic acid group in their side chains. This carboxylic acid group can ionize in solution to release a hydrogen ion, resulting in a negative charge. The negative charges on the aspartate and glutamate residues in fibrinopeptide A contribute to the overall negative charge of the peptide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histidine and lysine are positively charged amino acids that can form ionic bonds with negatively charged molecules, but they do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Options A and D Valine and serine are non-polar and uncharged amino acids that do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinopeptide A is a peptide that is cleaved from fibrinogen during blood clotting to form fibrin. Fibrin is a key component of blood clots and is responsible for stopping bleeding from injured blood vessels. Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues.

choices.text: Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer
Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity
Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion

questions.text: Which of the following accurately pairs the  diagnostic stain with the corneal condition it indicates? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

 

This is the correct match. Fluorescein, when used with a cobalt blue light, stains areas of corneal epithelial loss, highlighting defects such as corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer: Trypan blue is generally used in cataract surgery to stain the anterior capsule, not for diagnosing corneal ulcers.

 

Option B. Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity: Rose Bengal stain is actually used to detect damage to the eye's surface cells, particularly in cases of dry eye where these cells are more vulnerable. 

 

Option D. Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion: Lissamine green stains areas of cell loss or damage on the surface of the eye, such as in cases of corneal abrasion or dry eye. It’s used under white light rather than cobalt blue light.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorescein stain under cobalt blue light remains a standard and effective method for diagnosing corneal ulcers due to its ability to vividly highlight areas of epithelial loss.

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever. Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.

 

Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the recommended dietary allowance for iodine dosage among lactating women in India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 280 µg/day

 

As per the 2020 guidelines from the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN), the suggested dietary intake of iodine for lactating women in India is 280 micrograms per day.

 

NIN guidelines on recommended dietary allowance of Iodine -

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

India had adopted WHO guideline of Iodine requirement 150 mcg per day in Adults, 250 mcg per day in Pregnancy and 280 mcg per day in Lactation

questions.text: As per the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, the following combination is incorrect? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blue container – Incineration

 

The blue container is intended for the disposal of glassware and metallic implants. According to the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, these items should undergo autoclaving, hydroclaving, microwaving, or chemical treatment, followed by recycling. Incineration is not a recommended method for the blue container category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow bag – Deep burial: This is partially correct as deep burial is permitted for placentas at primary health centers, but generally, yellow bag waste is for incineration.

 

Option B. Yellow bag – Incineration: Correct as the yellow bag is primarily used for incinerating human anatomical waste, animal waste, microbiological and biotechnological waste, etc.

 

Option C. Red bag – Autoclaving: Correct as the red bag contains contaminated recyclable plastic and rubber material, which is treated via autoclaving, hydroclaving, or microwaving.

 

Additional Information

 

White container – For Sharps → autocalving/ dry heat → destruction shredding → iron foundries/ land fill/ sharp pits 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blue containers for biomedical waste should not be incinerated but treated and then recycled as per the guidelines.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serous Otitis media

 

Child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months with  air fluid levels on otoscopy is suggestive of serous otitis media.

 

Aetiology

 

  1. Eustachian tube block secondary to adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx
  2. Allergy
  3. Unresolved otitis media
  4. Viral infections – adeno and rhinovirus

 

Symptoms

 

The disease affects children of 5–8 years of age. The symptoms include:

 

  1. Conductive hearing loss.
  2. Delayed and defective speech. Because of hearing loss, development of speech is delayed or defective.
  3. Mild earaches.

 

Otoscopic Findings

 

  •  Tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex, and may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

Audiometry

 

  •  Pure tone audiometry shows conduction hearing loss
  •  Tympanometry will show B type curve

 

Treatment

 

1. Medical

 

  • Decongestants.
  • Antihistamines or sometimes steroids may be used in cases of allergy.
  • Antibiotics. They are useful in cases of upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Middle Ear Aeration. Patients should repeatedly perform the Valsalva maneuver. Children can be given chewing gum to encourage repeated swallowing which opens the tube.

 

2. Surgical

 

  • Myringotomy and fluid aspiration
  • Grommet insertion
  • Tympanotomy and mastoidectomy
  • Surgical treatment of underlying causes like adenoid hypertrophy, tonsillar hypertrophy etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myringitis bullosa involves the formation of blisters on the tympanic membrane due to inflammation, often associated with viral infections like influenza.

 

  • Symptoms: It is characterized by severe pain, occasionally hearing loss, and a rapid onset following an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The symptoms of prolonged hearing loss and the otoscopic findings of fluid levels visible in the image are not typical for myringitis bullosa, which usually presents with acute, painful blistering rather than effusion.

Option C. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, typically of rapid onset, involving signs of acute infection such as ear pain, fever, and general malaise.

 

  • Symptoms: The tympanic membrane often appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus and fluid, and the condition is usually accompanied by significant pain and fever.
  • Why Not: The child's symptoms described do not include acute infectious signs like significant pain or fever, and the duration of hearing loss suggests a more chronic condition.

Option D. Pneumo Tympanum refers to the presence of air in the middle ear space, which is not typically associated with fluid. It can occur due to trauma, barotrauma, or as a rare complication of severe nasal congestion.

 

  • Symptoms: This condition might present with a feeling of fullness or popping in the ear but not with the fluid level and air bubbles typically seen in fluid accumulation conditions.
  • Why Not: The presence of air bubbles alongside fluid specifically points towards fluid accumulation rather than just air, making pneumo tympanum less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media requires comprehensive management to prevent long-term effects on hearing and speech development. Early intervention, both medical and surgical, is essential for restoring normal ear function and preventing recurrent episodes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 84

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

 

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

 

Treatment of retinoblastoma –

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not commonly used for retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy, and a peripheral smear showing the presence of smudge cells suggest a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Immunophenotyping using flow cytometry is the investigation done to arrive at the diagnosis. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD 19+, CD20+, CD 23+, CD5+ and surface immunoglobulins of various classes, monoclonal light chains (λ or κ type).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): While PCR can be useful in certain hematologic malignancies for detecting specific genetic mutations, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH can be used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can provide additional prognostic information by identifying chromosomal abnormalities but is typically done after confirming the diagnosis with flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient suspected of having Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), Flow cytometry is the key diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

 

Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1114

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
  • When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels (pituitary apoplexy) and panhypopituitarism. It is characterized by:
    • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
    • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
    • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
    • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion
    • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor Syndrome: Also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin

 

Option C. Prolactinoma: This will not present lactation failure. Instead, there will be galactorrhea and symptoms like headache, luring of vision due to pressure effects of the prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: It is a disorder that results in excess growth of certain parts of the human body. It is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed. The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet. There may also be an enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose. Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision. Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:  Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.

 

Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-Arginine

 

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from L-arginine through the action of enzymes known as nitric oxide synthases (NOS). There are different forms of NOS enzymes, including endothelial NOS (eNOS) and neuronal NOS (nNOS), which are involved in the production of NO in various tissues and cells. L-arginine serves as the precursor for NO synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L-Citrulline: While L-citrulline is related to the nitric oxide pathway, it is not the direct precursor for NO synthesis. Instead, L-citrulline can be converted back into L-arginine in the body, and then L-arginine is used for NO production. This makes L-citrulline indirectly involved in the regulation of NO levels.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an amino acid with its own metabolic functions in the body but is not a precursor for NO.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine is also not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an essential amino acid with its own roles in protein synthesis and metabolism but is not part of the NO synthesis pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

 

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). It causes vasodilatation and acts through the formation of secondary messenger cGMP.

 

NOS (multienzyme complex)

 

  • There are three isoforms of NOS 
    1. iNOS- inducible
    2. nNOS - neuronal
    3. eNOS- endothelial

choices.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 wks
Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete.
Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 35 weeks+5 days gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is in labor pain. Examination of the cervix shows a 3 cm dilatation with a bag of liquor. What is the appropriate management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy.

 

This pregnant woman is presenting with symptoms and signs of severe pre-eclampsia, which include:

 

  • Epigastric pain
  • Headache
  • Blurring of vision
  • Severe hypertension: Blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg.

 

In the context of severe pre-eclampsia at 35 weeks+5 days gestation, the management should include:

 

  • Treating hypertension: Immediate blood pressure control is crucial to prevent complications such as eclampsia, stroke, or placental abruption.
  • Administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO4): This is done to prevent eclamptic seizures.
  • Consideration for termination of pregnancy: In cases of severe pre-eclampsia at or beyond 34 weeks, the recommended course of action is to expedite delivery to prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management: Conservative management is not appropriate for severe pre-eclampsia due to the high risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Option B. Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks: Tocolytics are contraindicated in severe pre-eclampsia as the goal is to deliver the baby as soon as the condition is stable, rather than delaying delivery.

 

Option C. Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete: As the patient is already beyond 34 weeks of gestation, steroid administration for fetal lung maturity is not necessary, and immediate delivery is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe pre-eclampsia at or beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate management involves controlling hypertension, administering magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures, and expediting delivery.

 

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1850,  Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg267

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate
Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

 

  • The patient most likely contracted syphilis through unprotected sexual intercourse and later developed neurosyphilis as a consequence (neurological and visual disturbances).
  • Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is a condition characterized by intact accommodation reflex, but absent light reflex in the affected eye. (ARP-PRA)
  • Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) are bilateral small pupils with the following characteristics:
  1. Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP):  Pupillary constriction when looking at near objects.
  2. Light Reflex absent: Do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light).
  • This is an example of light near dissociation.
  • Neurosyphilis is a manifestation of syphilis infection that affects the central nervous system, which occurs due to the invasion of the central nervous system by T. pallidum and can occur in any stage of syphilis.
  • Clinical features of neurosyphilis include:
    • Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs.
    • Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense.
    • Loss of reflexes in the legs.
    • Paraesthesia’s.
    • Bladder disturbances.
    • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting (visceral crisis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pupils react but do not accommodate: This is not characteristic of any specific condition and does not describe Argyll Robertson pupil.

 

Option C. Pupils neither react nor accommodate: This indicates more widespread dysfunction of the pupillary muscles and is not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. Pupils react and accommodate: This describes normal pupillary function, which would not be expected in the context of the described symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: G2 at 8 weeks diagnosed to have hyperthyroidism. What is the drug of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Propylthiouracil


Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred medication for treating hyperthyroidism in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is considered the safest option during this period because it minimizes the risk of congenital abnormalities. Methimazole and carbimazole are associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis, where infants are born with areas of missing skin. Iodine-131 is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy due to its radioactive nature, which can lead to fetal thyroid destruction and other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Although methimazole is commonly used for hyperthyroidism, it is not recommended during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its association with fetal defects like aplasia cutis, where patches of skin are absent in the newborn.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Similar to methimazole, carbimazole is contraindicated in the first trimester due to the risk of fetal malformations, specifically aplasia cutis. It is often avoided in early pregnancy.

 

Option C. Iodine 131: This radioactive iodine treatment is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cause severe fetal harm, including thyroid gland destruction and developmental issues, making it highly unsafe.

 

Educational Objective:


In the first trimester of pregnancy, propylthiouracil (PTU) is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism due to its safer profile compared to other antithyroid medications.
